$DATUM 1146576-61-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Arylazoles 3 and 4; General Procedure A sealed
tube equipped with a Teflon valve was charged with a magnetic stir bar,
CuBr (7 mg, 0.05 mmol, 5 mol%), Cs2CO3 (650 mg, 2 mmol) and any remaining
solids (azoles 2 and/or aryl halides 1). The tube was evacuated and
backfilled with N2 (3×). Under a counter flow of N2, azole 2 (1.2 mmol,
if liquid), aryl halide 1 (1 mmol, if liquid), DMSO (1.0 mL), and L1 (18
mg, 0.10 mmol, 10 mol%) were added by syringe. The tube was evacuated and
again backfilled with N2 (3×) and sealed. The mixture was heated to the
indicated temperature for the required time period. After cooling to
r.t., the mixture was diluted with EtOAc (25 mL), passed through a
fritted glass filter to remove the inorganic salts and the filtrate was
washed by H2O, brine, then removed under vacuum. The residue was purified
by column chromatography (silica gel) and the product was dried under
high vacuum (at least 1 h). 1-[4-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)phenyl]ethanone (3l)5t
1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ = 8.48 (s, 1 H), 8.15 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2 H),
7.94 (s, 1 H), 7.90 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2 H), 7.22 (s, 1 H), 2.67 (s, 3 H).
MS: m/z = 186.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Mild conditions for copper-catalyzed N-arylation of imidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Chen, Huaming; Wang, Deping; Wang, Xianyang; Huang, Wenlong; Cai, Qian;
Ding, Ke
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2010), (9), 1505-1511

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):AMD
$DATUM reaction products with sodium hydroxide and L-proline
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 960243-04-3

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Catalytic
N-Arylation of Nitrogen- Containing Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl
Halides. A flamedried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar was
charged with CuI (9.5 mg, 0.05 mmol), 4a-2 (145 mg, 0.1 mmol of the
L-proline unit), K2CO3 (165 mg, 1.2 mmol), nitrogen-containing
heterocycle (0.5 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide (0.6 mmol), and DMSO (2
mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced with a glass stopper, and the
system was then evacuated three times and backfilled with N2. The
reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature and then
heated at 120 °C for 60 h. The resulting mixture was cooled to ambient
temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate, filtered through a
plug of silica gel, and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl acetate. The
filtrate was concentrated, and the resulting residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel to provide the desired product.
1-(4-Imidazol-1-yl-phenyl)-ethanone (6d)3 Following the general
procedure, imidazole (0.034 g, 0.5 mmol) was coupled with
4-bromoacetophenone (0.120 g, 0.6 mmol) for 60 h at 90 ºC. The crude
product was purified over a silica gel column using ethyl acetate/petrol
ether (1/1) to give a white solid (92% yield). 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ
2.65 (s, 3H), 7.33 (bs, 1H), 7.45 (bs, 1H), 7.51 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H),
8.05 (bs, 1H), 8.09 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H) ppm. 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ
26.6, 117.7, 120.7, 130.3, 131.1, 135.4, 135.7, 140.7, 196.5 ppm. GC-MS
(EI, m/z): 186 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst (polymer-supported ionic liq. and its copper
complex)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A Concept of Supported Amino Acid Ionic Liquids and Their Application in

$DATUM Chen, Wen; Zhang, Yuanyuan; Zhu, Liangbo; Lan, Jingbo; Xie, Rugang; You,
Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129(45), 13879-13886

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: II. General procedure for the catalytic
N-arylation of nitrogen-containing heterocycles with aryl or heteroaryl
halides To a flame-dried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar
was charged with CuI (38.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.652 g, 2.0 mmol),
nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.4 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide
(1.0 mmol) and DMF (2 mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced with a
glass stopper, and the system was then evacuated twice and back filled
with N2. The reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature,
and then heated at 120 °C for 40 h. The reaction mixture was then cooled
to ambient temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate, filtered
through a plug of silica gel, and and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl
acetate. The combined organic extracts were concentrated and the
resulting residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to
provide the desired product. 1-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole (3a)2
1-(4-Imidazol-1-yl-phenyl)-ethanone (3b)1 Following the general
procedure, a white solid was obtained (92% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz,
CDCl3): δ 2.65 (s, 3H), 7.27 (bs, 1H), 7.39 (bs, 1H), 7.51 (d, J = 7.6
Hz, 2H), 7.99 (bs, 1H), 8.09 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H) ppm. 13C NMR (75 MHz,
CDCl3): δ 26.6, 117.7, 120.7, 130.3, 131.1, 135.4, 135.7, 140.7, 196.5
ppm. GC-MS (EI, m/z): 186 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Procedure: A mixture of
4-bromotoluene (1 mmol), imidazole (1.2 mmol), K2CO3 (2 mmol) and
Cu(II)-NaY (100 mg) in DMF (3 mL) was heated to 120 °C for the specified
time (Table 2). The progress of the reaction was monitored by GC or TLC.
The reaction mixture was filtered to separate the catalyst and the
filtrate was quenched with aq NaHCO3 and the product extracted with
EtOAc. The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over
Na2SO4 and concentrated. The residue was purified by column
chromatography to afford pure 1-(4-methylphenyl)-1H-imidazole.
1-(4-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (Table 2, entry 1), yield 92%. Mp 203 °C;
1H NMR (CDCl3): δ = 8.37 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 2 H), 7.93 (br s, 1 H), 7.58 (d,
J = 9.0 Hz, 2 H), 7.32 (br s, 1 H), 7.24 (br s, 1 H); MS (EI): m/z (%) =
189 (100), 159, 141, 116, 89, 50; Anal. Calcd for C9N3O2H7: C, 57.14; N,
22.2; H, 3.7; Found C, 57.42; N, 22.59; H, 3.19.

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Experimental Procedure for the
Arylation of Azole Azole (0.5 mmol), aromatic halide (0.5 mmol), CuI (10
mol%), ligand (10 mol%) and NaOMe (1 mmol) were located in a flask with
DMSO (1.5 mL). The mixture was heated at the corresponding temperature
for 12 h. The reaction mixture was filtrated by SiO2 and extracted with
EtOAc (3 × 8 mL). The combined organic was concentrated and subjected to
SiO2 column to give target products. 3l, yield 91%. 1H NMR (CDCl3,
500MHz): δ = 8.38-8.36 (m, 2H), 7.97 (s, 1H), 7.58-7.55 (m, 2H), 7.36 (s,
1H), 7.24 (s, 1H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 125MHz): δ = 146.6, 142.23, 135.7,
132.0, 126.0, 121.3, 117.9. ESI-MS: 190 [M+H]+.

$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Typical Experimental Procedure of N-Arylation under Heterogeneous
Conditions Catalyst 1f (0.050 g, 1 mol%) and K2CO3 (0.276 g, 2 mmol) were
added to a mixture of 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene (0.158 g, 1 mmol) and
imidazole (0.081 g, 1.2 mmol) in 4 mL of DMF. The reaction mixture was
heated at 110 °C under stirring for 4 h. After cooling to ambient
temperature, the resulting mixture was filtered off. and the catalyst was
washed several times with water and ethyl acetate to remove any excess
reagents and reused for the other cycle. The filtrate was extracted with
water, and the organic layer was dried over Na2SO4. This was concentrated
under vacuum, and the residue was purified by column chromatography on
silica gel to afford the product 1-(4-nitro-phenyl)-1H-imidazole in 91%
yield. 1-(4-nitro-phenyl)-1H-imidazole, yield 91%. Mp 203 °C; 1H NMR (300
MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.37 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 2H), 7.93 (br s, 1H), 7.58 (d, J = 9.0
Hz, 2H), 7.32 (br s, 1 H), 7.24 (br s, 1H); EI-MS: 189 (100%), 159, 141,
116, 89, 50; HRMS m/z 189.053 (calcd, for C9H7N3O2: 189.053): IR (KBr):
3130.96, 1599.57, 1528.72, 1340.33, 1052.66, 854.85 cm-1.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, optimized on catalysts
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-Arylation of heterocycles with chloro- and fluoroarenes using
resin-supported sulfonato-Cu(salen) complex
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kantam, M. Lakshmi; Ramani, T.; Chakrapani, L.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2008), 38(4), 626-636

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General procedure for the N-arylation of nitrogen nucleophiles Imidazole
(163.4 mg, 2.40 mmol), 38.1 mg CuI (0.20 mmol), 143.4 mg
1,4-bis(2-hydroxy-5-methoxybenzyl)piperazine (0.40 mmol), aryl halide
(2.00 mmol), 225 mg KOH (4.0 mmol), 64.4 mg (n-Bu)4NBr (0.20 mmol), and 2
cm 3 water were put into a Teflon septum screw-capped tube and then
sealed in the air. The reaction mixture was stirred at 120 °C for 12 h.
After cooling to room temperature, ethyl acetate (3 x 1 cm3) was added to
extract the coupling product and results were determined by GC. The pure
N-arylated product was obtained by column chromatography on silica gel.
All products were known and characterized by 1H NMR spectroscopy, the
data were found to be identical with those reported in the literature.
1-phenyl-1H-imidazole (3a), yield 92%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 7.86
(s, 1H), 7.46-7.50 (m, 2H), 7.35-7.40 (m, 3H), 7.29 (br s, 1H), 7.21 (br
s, 1H) ppm. MS ( EI , M/Z): 144 [M+], 117, 90, 77.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry, green chemistry (protocol), green chemistry-solvent,
optimized on ligand and base, sealed tube used, alternative preparation
shown, optimization study
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Simple synthesized Mannich bases as ligands in Cu-catalyzed N-arylation
of imidazoles in water
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhu, Yefeng; Shi, Yixing; Wei, Yunyang
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Monatshefte fuer Chemie (2010), 141(9), 1009-1013

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General procedures for the coupling reactions of aryl or 2-thienyl
bromides with imidazole or pyrazole using 1 as catalyst: Under dinitrogen
atmosphere, a Schlenk flask equipped with a magnetic stirring bar was
charged with 1 (25.4 mg, 5.8 μmol), Ar-Br (1.5 mmol), HN-cycle (2.25
mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.98 g, 3 mmol), and solvent (3 mL) predried with CaH2.
The reaction was carried out in a closed system at elevated temperature
for the required time. After workup, the mixture was diluted with
dichloromethane (15 mL) and filtered to remove insoluble stuff.
Evaporating to dryness, the residue was purified by flash chromatography
on silica gel (3 x 15 cm, petroleum ether and ethyl acetate as an eluent
(10:1)). The fractions obtained were dried and measured by 1H and 13C NMR
spectroscopy. N-phenyl-imidazole (the product of run 1) 1H NMR (400 MHz,
CDCl3, 298 K, ppm): δ = 7.09 (br, 1 H), 7.16 (br, 1 H), 7.74 (br, 1 H)
(imidazole ring-H), 7.22-7.28 (m, 3 H), 7.33-7.38 (m, 2 H) (C6H5); 13C
NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3, 298 K, ppm): δ = 118.27, 135.59, 137.33 (imidazole
ring-C), 121.47, 127.51, 129.89, 130.33 (C6H5).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM chemoselective, sealed tube used, Ullmann reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Cu24O24Si8R8: Organic Soluble 56-Membered Copper(I) Siloxane Cage and Its

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Copper-Catalyzed
Coupling of Nitrogen Heterocycles and Aryl Bromides A flame-dried Schlenk
test tube with a magnetic stirring bar was charged with CuBr (14 mg, 0.1
mmol), ligand (30 mg, 0.2 mmol), Cs2CO3 (652 mg, 2.0 mmol), amine or
nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.0 mmol), aryl halide (1.2 mmol) and
DMSO (1 mL) under N2. After the reaction mixture was heated at 80°C for
12 h or at 90°C for 24 h, the reaction mixture was cooled to ambient
temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate, filtered through a
plug of silica gel, and washed with 10 mL of ethyl acetate. The filtrate
was concentrated and the resulting residue was purified by column
chromatography on silica gel (ethyl acetate/petroleum ether) to provide
the desired product. 1-phenyl-1H-imidazole (2e) Following the general
procedure, imidazole (68 mg, 1.0 mmol) was coupled with bromobenzene (126
μL, 1.2 mmol) at the indicated condition. The crude product was purified
over a silica gel column using ethyl acetate/petrol ether (1:2-2:1, v/v)
giving yellow oil. Yield 92% 1H NMR (400MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.86 (s, 1H),
7.46-7.50 (m, 2H), 7.34-7.40 (m, 3H), 7.29 (s, 1H), 7.21 (s, 1H); 13C NMR
(100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 137.1, 135.5, 130.2, 129.6, 127.4, 121.2, 118.1; GC-MS
(EI, m/z) 144 [M+]5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM 1,2,3,4-Tetrahydro-8-hydroxyquinoline-promoted copper-catalyzed coupling
of nitrogen nucleophiles and aryl bromides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Wang, Huifeng; Li, Yaming; Sun, Fangfang; Feng, Yang; Jin, Kun; Wang,
Xiuna
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2008), 73(21), 8639-8642

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2.2 Typical Experimental Procedure A mixture
of aryl halide (1 mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.5 mmol), Cu2O
(0.1 mmol), KOH (2 mmol) and DMSO (2 mL) was stirred at the temperature
specified under Ar atmosphere until nearly complete conversion of aryl
halide as monitored by GC or TLC, the cooled mixture was partitioned
between ethyl acetate (10 mL) and water (3 mL). The organic layer was
separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate (5 mL).
The combined organic layers were washed with brine (5 mL), dried over
Na2SO4, and concentrated to give the crude product, which was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel (200–300 mesh) using ethyl
acetate/methanol as eluent. Entry: 12 Yield: 91% 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3):
δ = 7.85 (s, 1H), 7.49–7.45 (m, 2H), 7.39–7.34 (m, 3H), 7.28 (s, 1H),
7.21 (s, 1H) ppm; 13C NMR (100.6 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 137.4, 135.7, 130.5,
130.0 (2C), 127.6, 121.5 (2C), 118.3 ppm; GC/MS (EI) m/z (%): 145 (11),
144 (100), 117 (47), 90 (36), 89 (12), 77 (28), 51 (16); IR (thin film,
neat) cm-1: 3118, 1598, 1509, 1304, 1252, 1110, 1059, 908, 760, 689, 661,
520.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: II. General procedure for the catalytic
N-arylation of nitrogen-containing heterocycles with aryl or heteroaryl
halides To a flame-dried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar
was charged with CuI (38.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.652 g, 2.0 mmol),
nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.4 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide
(1.0 mmol) and DMF (2 mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced with a
glass stopper, and the system was then evacuated twice and back filled
with N2. The reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature,
and then heated at 120 °C for 40 h. The reaction mixture was then cooled
to ambient temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate, filtered
through a plug of silica gel, and and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl
acetate. The combined organic extracts were concentrated and the
resulting residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to
provide the desired product. 1-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole (3a)2
1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (3i)2 Following the general procedure, pale yellow
oil was obtained (91% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.24 (s, 1 H),
7.31 (s, 1H), 7.36-7.40 (m, 3H), 7.47 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 2H), 7.89 (s, 1H)
ppm. 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 118.3, 121.5, 127.5, 129.9, 130.3,
135.7, 137.3 ppm. GC-MS (EI, m/z): 144 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Simple Copper Salt-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing
Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhu, Liangbo; Guo, Peng; Li, Gaocan; Lan, Jingbo; Xie, Rugang; You,
Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(22), 8535-8538

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for Cu(I)-Catalyzed Coupling
Reactions of Phenyl Halide with Imidazole. CuI/1,10-Phenanthroline asthe
Catalyst. A 50 mL oven-dried Schlenk tube containing a stirbar was
quickly charged with CuI (0.019 g, 0.10 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline
(1,10-phen) (0.036 g, 0.20 mmol), imidazole (0.068g, 1.0 mmol), and the
base Cs2CO3 (0.650 g, 2.0 mmol). The tubewas sealed and evacuated and
refilled with N2. Predried phenylhalide (1.0 mL), after being bubbled
with N2, was transferred intothe Schlenk tube via syringe. The mixture
was heated in an oilbath under appropriate temperature for 19 or 48 h.
After beingcooled to room temperature, the reaction mixture was diluted
with20 mL of water and was extracted with CH2Cl2 (3 x20 mL). After the
solvent was removed, the residue was purified by chromatographyon a
silica gel column with ethyl acetate/hexanes (4:1) as the eluent. Yield
91%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative preparation shown, alternative reaction conditions gave lower
yield

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Experimental Procedure for the
Arylation of Azole Azole (0.5 mmol), aromatic halide (0.5 mmol), CuI (10
mol%), ligand (10 mol%) and NaOMe (1 mmol) were located in a flask with
DMSO (1.5 mL). The mixture was heated at the corresponding temperature
for 12 h. The reaction mixture was filtrated by SiO2 and extracted with
EtOAc (3 × 8 mL). The combined organic was concentrated and subjected to
SiO2 column to give target products. 4a, yield 92%. 1H NMR (CDCl3,
500MHz): δ = 8.41 (dd, 1H), 8.30 (s, 1H), 7.78-7.74 (m, 1H), 7.60 (s,
1H), 7.31 (t, 1H), 7.18 (dd, 1H), 7.14 (s, 1H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 125MHz):
δ = 149.3, 139.2, 135.2, 130.7, 122.2, 116.4, 112.5. ESI-MS: 146 [M+H]+.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N,N'-(phenylmethylene)diacetamide analogues as economical and efficient
ligands in copper-catalyzed arylation of aromatic nitrogen-containing
heterocycles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7681-65-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 30754-24-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for N-Arylation of Imidazole
with Aryl Bromides. A Schlenk tube equipped with a Teflon stopcock are
charged with a magnetic stir bar, K2CO3 (572 mg, 2.1 mmol), CuI (0.38 mg,
0.20 mmol, 20 mol %), and per-6-amino- β -cyclodextrin (100 mg, 0.08
mmol, 8 mol %). DMSO (1 mL) was added at room temperature. Then a
solution of bromobenzene (188 mg, 1.2 mmol) and imidazole (68 mg, 1.0
mmol) in DMSO (1 mL) was added. The tube was sealed and the mixture was
allowed to stir for 24 h at 110°C. Water (5 mL) was added to the reaction
mixture after completion of the reaction. Then it was extracted with
ethyl acetate (3 × 20 mL) and the combined organic layers were dried with
anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated by vacuum. The residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel, using hexane/ethyl acetate (1:3) as
eluant, to give an oil of 1-phenylimidazole 4a (164 mg, 98%)
2-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)pyridine (4p), yield 92% 1H NMR (400 MHz): 8.47 (bs,
1H), 8.36 (bs, 1H), 7.83- 7.79 (m,1H), 7.64 - 7.63 (t, 1H), 7.36-7.34 (m,
1H), 7.26- 7.19 (m, 1H) 13C NMR (100 MHz): 149.1, 139.0, 135.0, 130.4,
121.4, 116.1, 112.3 GC-MS: m/z 144.9 (M+)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM sealed tube used, Ullmann reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Per-6-amino-β-cyclodextrin as an Efficient Supramolecular Ligand and Host
for Cu(I)-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Imidazole with Aryl Bromides

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2.2 Typical Experimental Procedure A mixture
of aryl halide (1 mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.5 mmol), Cu2O
(0.1 mmol), KOH (2 mmol) and DMSO (2 mL) was stirred at the temperature
specified under Ar atmosphere until nearly complete conversion of aryl
halide as monitored by GC or TLC, the cooled mixture was partitioned
between ethyl acetate (10 mL) and water (3 mL). The organic layer was
separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate (5 mL).
The combined organic layers were washed with brine (5 mL), dried over
Na2SO4, and concentrated to give the crude product, which was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel (200–300 mesh) using ethyl
acetate/methanol as eluent. Entry: 11 Yield: 91%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Cu2O: a Simple and Efficient Reusable Catalyst for N-arylation of
Nitrogen-containing Heterocycles with Aryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Huang, Yi-Zheng; Miao, Hong; Zhang, Qiao-Hong; Chen, Chen; Xu, Jie
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Catalysis Letters (2008), 122(3-4), 344-348

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 31072-40-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for N-Boc protection of
amines. Amine (5 mmol) was added to the mixture of (Boc)2O (5 mmol) and
poly(4-vinylpyridinium) perchlorate [31-33] (50 mg, 0.85 mol%) with
constant stirring at room temperature. After completion of the reaction
(monitored by TLC), ethyl acetate (395 cm3) was added to the reaction
mixture and the catalyst was decanted and washed with ethyl acetate (295
cm3) and dried. The product was purified by column chromatography, using
ethyl acetatepetroleum ether (2:8) eluent. The physical and spectral data
of known compounds were in agreement with those reported in the
literature. Entry; 9, yield; 92%. M.p; 43-44%, Lit. m.p; 42-45%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM chemoselective, green chemistry-catalyst, solid-supported catalyst, no
solvent, reusable catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM The chemoselective N-Boc protection of amines in the presence of
solid-supported perchloric acid as an efficient and reusable solid acid
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Khaligh, Nader Ghaffari; Hazarkhani, Hassan
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Monatshefte fuer Chemie (2014), 145(12), 1975-1980

$DATUM 905707-77-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):AMD
$DATUM (vinyl)pyridine-chlorosulfonic acid polymer
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the synthesis of
N-tert-butylcarbamates. Amine (1 mmol) was added to a magnetically
stirred mixture of (Boc)2O (1 mmol) and NSPVPC (5 mg). After completion
of the reaction (monitored by TLC), ethyl acetate (15 mL) was added to
the reaction mixture and the catalyst was recovered by filtration and
washed with ethyl acetate (2 × 5 mL) and dried. The product was purified
by column chromatography, using ethyl acetate-etroleum ether (2:8) as
eluent. Entry 11, Yield: 92%. Time: 2 min.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM no solvent, recyclable catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DATUM 92
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure: To Boc2O (1 mmol) that was
being magnetically stirred in oven-dried glassware at r.t. was added the
amine (1 mmol). Rapid heat evolution and bubbling was then observed. The
mixture was stirred until completion of the reaction. The product was
purified using silica gel column chromatography eluting with hexane-EtOAc
(5:1) to afford the corresponding N-Boc protected product. All of the
products are known and were characterized by comparison of their spectral
data with those of authentic samples. Table 1, Entry 6, yield 92%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Environmentally benign N-Boc protection under solvent- and catalyst-free
conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Jia, Xueshun; Huang, Qing; Li, Jian; Li, Shaoyu; Yang, Qiushi
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Procedure of N-Arylation
under Heterogeneous Conditions Catalyst 1f (0.050 g, 1 mol%) and K2CO3
(0.276 g, 2 mmol) were added to a mixture of 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene
(0.158 g, 1 mmol) and imidazole (0.081 g, 1.2 mmol) in 4 mL of DMF. The
reaction mixture was heated at 110 °C under stirring for 4 h. After
cooling to ambient temperature, the resulting mixture was filtered off.
and the catalyst was washed several times with water and ethyl acetate to
remove any excess reagents and reused for the other cycle. The filtrate
was extracted with water, and the organic layer was dried over Na2SO4.
This was concentrated under vacuum, and the residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel to afford the product
1-(4-nitro-phenyl)-1H-imidazole in 91% yield. Table 4, Entry 5, yield
92%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-Arylation of heterocycles with chloro- and fluoroarenes using
resin-supported sulfonato-Cu(salen) complex
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kantam, M. Lakshmi; Ramani, T.; Chakrapani, L.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2008), 38(4), 626-636

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Experimental Procedure Azole (1 mmol),
aryl halide (1.2 mmol), Cu(OH)2 · CuCO3 (15 mol%), ligand (L1) (20 mol%),
K2CO3 (2 mmol), and water (2 mL) were mixed in an Erlenmeyer flask (5 mL)
fitted with a reflux condenser and refluxed on an oil bath for the
stipulated period of time. After the completion of the reaction
(monitored by TLC), 20 mL of EtOAc was added to the reaction mixture
after transfer to a beaker (50 mL) and stirred for several minutes. The
mixture was then filtered through a bed of celite, and the organic layer
was separated by the separating funnel, which was washed successively
with water (2 x 10 mL) and brine (2 x 10 mL). The organic layer was dried
with anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated by reduced pressure in a rotary
evaporator. Finally, the products were purified by column chromatography
using neutral alumina as the column material and EtOAc and petroleum
ether (60-80 °C) as eluant. The IR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR, and analytical data
of all previously unknown compounds are given.
1-(2,5-Dichlorophenyl)-2-methyl-1H-imidazole (3c, Table 2, Entry 4) Entry
1. Product 3a. Yield 92%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry-catalyst, Ullmann-type coupling, alternative preparation
shown
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Highly Efficient and Simple Catalytic System for the N-Arylation of Some
Hindered Aza-Heterocycles in Water
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Mukhopadhyay, Chhanda; Tapaswi, Pradip Kumar
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2012), 42(15), 2217-2228

$DATUM nitrated, reduced, copper diacetate complex of Schiff base with

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General procedure for the N-arylation of imidazole with iodobenzene
catalyzed by homogeneous copper(II) Schiff base catalyst In a 100 mL RB
flask, homogeneous copper catalyst (0.0156 mmol), iodobenzene (1 mmol),
imidazole (1.2 mmol), K2CO3 (2 mmol), and DMSO (10 mL) were stirred under
nitrogen atmosphere at 120 °C. After the completion of the reaction, the
filtrate was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 x 20 mL) and the combined
organic layers were dried with anhydrous Na2SO4. The filtrate was
concentrated by vacuum, then the reaction mixture was identified by GC-MS
and quantified by GC analysis. 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (A), yield 92%. 1H
NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 7.82 (s, 1H), 7.54-7.42 (m, 2H), 7.41-7.40 (m,
3H), 7.27 (bs, 1H), 7.24 (bs, 1H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 136.4,
134.5, 130.5, 129.0, 126.9, 121.1, 118.2.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, polymer-supported copper(II) schiff base
complex prepared and used as catalyst, optimization study, optimized on
catalyst, base and solvent, reaction unsuccessful in absence of catalyst,
catalyst recycled, alternative preparations shown

$DATUM An efficient polymer-supported copper(II) catalyst for the N-arylation

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 1-(2-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (2e); Typical
Procedure. A mixture of 1-chloro-2-nitrobenzene (1 mmol), 1H-imidazole
(1.2 mmol), K2CO3 (1.2 mmol), and Cu/Al-HTB (100 mg, 2.5 mol%) in DMF (2
mL) was stirred in a round-bottomed flask at 100 °C. When the reaction
was complete (TLC), the catalyst was filtered washed several times with
DMF, H2O and acetone and reused for the next reaction. DMF was removed
from the reaction filtrate under reduced pressure and crude material was
purified by chromatography (silica gel, 60-120 mesh, hexane-EtOAc) to
afford 2e.11 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (2a)11. Yield 92%. 1H NMR (300 MHz,
CDCl3): δ = 7.21 (br s, 1 H), 7.29 (br s, 1 H), 7.34-7.40 (m, 3 H),
7.46-7.51 (m, 2 H), 7.87 (s, 1 H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 118.2,
121.3, 127.4, 129.7, 130.1, 135.5, 137.1. GC-MS: m/z = 144 (M+). Anal.
Calcd for C9H8N2: C, 74.98; H, 5.59; N, 19.43. Found: C, 75.15; H, 5.58;
N, 19.41.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry-catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Cu-Al hydrotalcite: an efficient and reusable ligand-free catalyst for
the coupling of aryl chlorides with aliphatic, aromatic, and
N(H)-heterocyclic amines

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General procedure for N-arylation of nitrogen nucleophiles: Imidazole
(75.0 mg, 1.10 mmol), CuSO4·5H2O (25.0 mg, 0.1 mmol),
1,2-bis(2-pyridyl)-ethane-N,N’-dioxides (41.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), aryl halide
(1.00 mmol), Cs2CO3 (652 mg, 2.0 mmol) and water (3 mL) were put into a
Teflon septum screw-capped tube and then sealed in the air. The reaction
mixture was stirred at 120 °C for 24 h. After cooled to room temperature,
ethyl acetate was added to extract the coupling product and results were
determined by GC/MS. The pure N-arylated product was finally obtained by
column chromatography on silica gel. All the products were confirmed by
1H NMR and 13C NMR spectroscopic analysis. 1-phenyl-1H-imidazole[1] (1)
Following the general procedure using 1H-imidazole (75 mg, 1.1 mmol) and
iodobenzene (112 µL, 1 mmol) provided 131 mg (91% yield) of the coupling
product as a colorless oil after purification by flash chromatography
(eluent: ethyl acetate/petrol ether =1/1). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ
7.74 (s, 1H), 7.34-7.39 (m, 2H), 7.21-7.25 (m, 3H), 7.14 (s, 1H), 7.12
(s, 1H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): 137.15, 135.39, 130.32, 129.84,
127.25, 121.39, 118.22. MS (EI, M/Z): 144 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM optimized on catalyst, reagent and ligand, optimization study
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Pyridine N-Oxides as Ligands in Cu-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Imidazoles in
Water
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Liang, Lei; Li, Zhengkai; Zhou, Xiangge
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Organic Letters (2009), 11(15), 3294-3297

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical procedure for C-N cross coupling
reaction: To a stirred solution of amine (1.2 mmol), iodobenzene (1 mmol)
and KOH (1 mmol) in DMSO (1 mL), CuO nanoparticle (1.26 mol%) was added.
The solution was heated at 110 °C for the appropriate time. The progress
of the reactions was monitored by TLC. The reaction mixture was then
cooled to room temperature and treated with ethyl acetate (10 mL) and
water (3 mL). The aqueous layer was separated and extracted with ethyl
acetate (3 x 5 mL). The combined organic solution, after successively
washed with brine (3 x 5 mL) and water (1 x 5 mL), dried (Na2SO4) and
passed through a short pad of celite. Evaporation of the solvent provided
a residue which was purified on silica gel column chromatography using
ethyl acetate and hexane as eluent. N-(Phenyl)imidazole, colorless
liquid, yield 91%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.87 (s, 1H), 7.50-7.47 (m,
2H), 7.40-7.37 (m, 3H), 7.29 (s, 1H), 7.21 (s, 1H); 13C NMR (100 MHz,
CDCl3) δ 137.47, 135.76, 130.46, 130.06, 127.70, 121.66, 118.45, 107.38.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Novel CuO Nanoparticle Catalyzed C-N Cross Coupling of Amines with
Iodobenzene
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Rout, Laxmidhar; Jammi, Suribabu; Punniyamurthy, T.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Organic Letters (2007), 9(17), 3397-3399

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME15 STEP1

$DATUM 142-71-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):AMD
$DATUM polymer-supported
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 9003-53-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):AMD
$DATUM nitrated, reduced, copper diacetate complex of Schiff base with
2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the N-arylation of
imidazole with iodobenzene catalyzed by homogeneous copper(II) Schiff
base catalyst In a 100 mL RB flask, homogeneous copper catalyst (0.0156
mmol), iodobenzene (1 mmol), imidazole (1.2 mmol), K2CO3 (2 mmol), and
DMSO (10 mL) were stirred under nitrogen atmosphere at 120 °C. After the
completion of the reaction, the filtrate was extracted with ethyl acetate
(3 x 20 mL) and the combined organic layers were dried with anhydrous
Na2SO4. The filtrate was concentrated by vacuum, then the reaction
mixture was identified by GC-MS and quantified by GC analysis.
1-(4-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (E) [39], yield 92% 1H NMR (400 MHz,
CDCl3) δ: 8.39 (d, 2H), 7.99 (bs, 1H), 7.58 (d, 2H), 7.38 (bs, 1H), 7.28
(bs, 1H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 146.3, 141.9, 135.4, 131.7, 125.7,
121.0, 117.6.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, polymer-supported copper(II) schiff base
complex prepared and used as catalyst, catalyst recyclable, alternative
preparation shown
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM An efficient polymer-supported copper(II) catalyst for the N-arylation
reaction of N(H)-heterocycles with aryl halides as well as arylboronic
acids
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Islam, Manirul; Mondal, Sanchita; Mondal, Paramita; Roy, Anupam Singha;
Tuhina, Kazi; Salam, Noor; Paul, Sumantra; Hossain, Dildar; Mobarok,
Manir
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Transition Metal Chemistry (Dordrecht, Netherlands) (2011), 36(4),
447-458

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 1-(2-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (2e); Typical Procedure. A mixture of
1-chloro-2-nitrobenzene (1 mmol), 1H-imidazole (1.2 mmol), K2CO3 (1.2
mmol), and Cu/Al-HTB (100 mg, 2.5 mol%) in DMF (2 mL) was stirred in a
round-bottomed flask at 100 °C. When the reaction was complete (TLC), the
catalyst was filtered washed several times with DMF, H2O and acetone and
reused for the next reaction. DMF was removed from the reaction filtrate
under reduced pressure and crude material was purified by chromatography
(silica gel, 60-120 mesh, hexane-EtOAc) to afford 2e.11
1-(2-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (2e). Yield 92%. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3):
δ = 7.36-7.56 (m, 6 H), 7.85 (d, J = 7.93 Hz, 1 H). 13C NMR (75 MHz,
CDCl3): δ = 122.0, 124.1, 124.6, 125.5, 129.9, 132.0, 135.5, 137.4,
139.9. MS (EI): m/z = 43, 57, 83, 85, 109, 115, 128, 149, 164, 171, 189
(M+). Anal. Calcd for C9H7N3O2: C, 57.14; H, 3.73; N, 22.21. Found: C,
57.15; H, 3.69; N, 22.30.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry-catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Cu-Al hydrotalcite: an efficient and reusable ligand-free catalyst for
the coupling of aryl chlorides with aliphatic, aromatic, and
N(H)-heterocyclic amines
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Sreedhar, B.; Arundhathi, R.; Reddy, P. Linga; Reddy, M. Amarnath;
Kantam, M. Lakshmi
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2009), (15), 2517-2522

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Procedure for the Aza-Michael Reaction
of Amines with α,β-Unsaturated Carbonyls or Nitriles In a typical
procedure, catalyst (5 mol%) was added to a mixture of α,β-unsaturated
olefin (1.2mmol) and amine (1mmol) and stirred at room temperature. After
completion of reaction (as monitored by TLC), the reaction mixture was
diluted with ether, and the catalyst was centrifuged and washed with
ether. The combined organic layer was concentrated to give the crude
product. Column chromatography was performed using silica gel (60-120
mesh) to afford the pure β-amino adduct. The products were characterized
by comparison of their 1H NMR, IR, mass spectra, and elemental analysis
with those of authentic samples.[20,24] Table 2 Entry 9, yield 92%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES

$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2008), 38(20), 3556-3566

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 4,5-Diiodoimidazole (7).21 An aqueous solution (500 mL) of imidazole
(30.0 g, 0.441 mol) was added dropwise to a solution of KICl2 (2.0 M, 550
mL, 1.1 mol, prepared from dissolving ICl (79.9 g, 1.03 mol) in an
aqueous solution of KCl (131.5 g, 1.77 mol in 550 mL of H2O) at rt. The
mixture was stirred for an additional 10 h, followed by slow addition of
2 M NaOH solution until the suspension was completely dissolved. The
clear solution was then acidified to pH 9.50 by dropwise addition of
concentrated HCl. The resulting product was filtered to afford an
off-white powder, which, following recrystallization in EtOH, gave 7 as a
white crystalline solid (131.2 g, 93%). mp 188-191 °C; 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) δ
7.76 (s, 1 H); 13C NMR (DMSO-d6) δ 141.1, 143.2.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Procedure B: Coupling of Aryl halides
with Amides, Imidazoles, Phenols or Thiols. (Table 2, entry 4): An
oven-dried Schlenk tube equipped with a Teflon valve was charged with a
magnetic stir bar, Cs2CO3 (684 mg, 2.1 mmol), CuBr (15 mg, 0.10 mmol, 10
mol%), and ethyl 2-oxocyclohexanecarboxylate (34 mg, 0.20 mmol, 20 mol%)
The tube was evacuated and backfilled with N2 (this procedure was
repeated three times). Under a counter flow of N2, DMSO (0.5 mL) was
added by syringe at room temperature (25-30 °C) and pre-stirred for 0.5
h. Then a solution of 1-iodo-4-methylbenzene (218 mg, 1.0 mmol),
2-pyrrolidinone (102 mg, 1.2 mmol) in DMSO (0.5 mL) was added via syringe
under a counter flow of N2. The tube was sealed and the mixture was
allowed to stir for 24 h at 60 ºC. The reaction mixture was directly
passed through celite. After rinsed with further 60 mL of ethyl acetate,
the combined filtrate was washed by saturated brine (10 ml × 2). After
the organic layer was dried by Na2SO4, it was concentrated by rotatory
evaporation. The residue was purified bycolumn chromatography on silica
gel using hexane/ethyl acetate (1:1) as eluent to give a white solid of
1-p-tolylpyrrolidin-2-one (151 mg, 86 %). 1d, 1-p-tolylpyrrolidin-2-one4
(Table 2, entry 4, 10) 2e, 1-(4-methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole1 (Table 3,
entry 8) Procedure B was followed. Yellow solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3)
δ 7.72 (1H, s), 7.25-7.27 (2H, m), 7.15-7.17 (2H, m), 6.94-6.96 (2H, m),
3.81 (3H, s); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 158.8, 135.8, 130.6, 130.0,
123.1, 118.7, 114.8, 55.5 (CDCl3 δ 77.0).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the systhesis of diaryl
amines: A Schlenk tube equipped with a magnetic stir bar was charged with
p-toluidine (2a, 80 mg, 0.75 mmol), K2CO3 (138 mg, 1 mmol), Fe(acac) 3
(34.4 mg, 20% mol) and Cu(OAc)2·H2O (20 mg, 20% mol). Under a nitrogen
atmosphere, bromobenzene (1a, 0.5mmol, 78.0 mg) was added followed by dry
DMF (0.8 mL). The reaction mixture was then heated in an oil bath of
135°C. After being stirred at this temperature for 20 h, the mixture was
cooled to room temperature and diluted with diethyl ether. The resulting
suspension was directly filtered through a pad of celite and the filtrate
was concentrated and the crude mixtures were purified by column
chromatography on silica gel (300-400 mesh) using petroleum ether/ethyl
acetate solvent mixture as the eluent. 1-(4-chlorophenyl)-1H-imidazole.
Yield: 92%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): 7.83 (s, 1H), 7.45 (d, J = 8.6 Hz,
2H), 7.33 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H), 7.25 (s, 1H), 7.21 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (100
MHz, CDCl3): 136.20, 135.83, 133.46, 131.04, 130.34, 122.99, 118.49. HRMS
(EI+): calcd for C9H7N2Cl (M+): 178.0298, found 178.0301.

$DATUM 9003-53-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):AMD
$DATUM nitrated, reduced, copper diacetate complex of Schiff base with
2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-56-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the N-arylation of
N(H)-heterocycles with arylboronic acids catalyzed by heterogeneous
copper(II) Schiff base catalyst In a 100 mL RB flask, copper(II) catalyst
(0.05 g, 0.0156 mmol), aryl boronic acid (1.5 mmol), N(H)-heterocycles
(1.2 mmol), and MeOH (10 mL) were stirred under open air, at 40 °C. To
study the progress of the reaction, the reaction mixtures were collected
at different time intervals and quantified by GC analysis. After the
completion of the reaction, the catalyst was filtered off, washed with
water followed by acetone, and oven dried. Then, it was extracted with
ethyl acetate (3 x 20 mL), and the combined organic layers were dried
with anhydrous Na2SO4. The filtrate was concentrated by vacuum, and the
resulting residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to
provide the desired product. 1-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole (C) [40],
yield 92% 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 7.70 (s, 1H), 7.25 (d, 2H, J= 9.0
Hz), 7.15 (bs, 1H), 7.13 (bs, 1H), 6.97 (d, 2H, J= 9.0 Hz), 3.81 (s, 3H);
13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 158.8, 135.6, 131.2, 130.6, 120 (2C), 118.4,
114.7 (2C), 55.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, polymer-supported copper(II) schiff base
complex prepared and used as catalyst, catalyst recyclable, alternative
preparation decreased yield
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM An efficient polymer-supported copper(II) catalyst for the N-arylation
reaction of N(H)-heterocycles with aryl halides as well as arylboronic
acids
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Islam, Manirul; Mondal, Sanchita; Mondal, Paramita; Roy, Anupam Singha;
Tuhina, Kazi; Salam, Noor; Paul, Sumantra; Hossain, Dildar; Mobarok,
Manir
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Transition Metal Chemistry (Dordrecht, Netherlands) (2011), 36(4),
447-458

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1311157-16-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):AMD
$DATUM polymer-supported
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-56-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: In a 100 mL RB flask, Cu-PAR (0.05 g, 0.0129
mmol), arylboronic acid (1 mmol), N-H heterocycles (1.2 mmol), and 10 mL
methanol were stirred under nitrogen atmosphere, at 40 °C. The reaction
mixtures were collected at different time interval and identified by GCMS
and quantified by GC analysis. After the completion of the reaction, the
catalyst was filtered off and washed with water fol- lowed by acetone and
dried in oven. The filtrate was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 20 mL)
and the com- bined organic layers were dried with anhydrous Na2SO4 by
vacuum. The filtrate was concentrated by vacuum and the resulting residue
was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to provide the
desired product. 1-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole (C). Time (h): 14,
Isolated Yield (%): 91. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.71 (s, 1H), 7.28 (d,
2H, J= 9.0 Hz), 7.15 (bs, 1H), 7.11 (bs, 1H), 6.94 (d, J= 9.0 Hz, 2H),
3.83 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 159.0, 135.8, 130, 130.8, 123
(2C), 118.5, 114.6, (2C), 55.2.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, catalyst prepared and used, chloromethylated
polystyrene-supported copper(II) 4-(2-pyridylazo)resorcinol complex
catalyst used, alternative preparation shown
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM An Efficient Recyclable Polymer Supported Copper(II) Catalyst for C-N
Bond Formation by N-Arylation
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Islam, Manirul; Mondal, Sanchita; Mondal, Paramita; Roy, Anupam Singha;
Tuhina, Kazi; Mobarok, Manir; Paul, Sumantra; Salam, Noor; Hossain,
Dildar
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Catalysis Letters (2011), 141(8), 1171-1181

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Arylazoles 3 and 4; General Procedure A sealed
tube equipped with a Teflon valve was charged with a magnetic stir bar,
CuBr (7 mg, 0.05 mmol, 5 mol%), Cs2CO3 (650 mg, 2 mmol) and any remaining
solids (azoles 2 and/or aryl halides 1). The tube was evacuated and
backfilled with N2 (3×). Under a counter flow of N2, azole 2 (1.2 mmol,
if liquid), aryl halide 1 (1 mmol, if liquid), DMSO (1.0 mL), and L1 (18
mg, 0.10 mmol, 10 mol%) were added by syringe. The tube was evacuated and
again backfilled with N2 (3×) and sealed. The mixture was heated to the
indicated temperature for the required time period. After cooling to
r.t., the mixture was diluted with EtOAc (25 mL), passed through a
fritted glass filter to remove the inorganic salts and the filtrate was
washed by H2O, brine, then removed under vacuum. The residue was purified
by column chromatography (silica gel) and the product was dried under
high vacuum (at least 1 h). 1-(4-Bromophenyl)-1H-imidazole (3d)5e 1H NMR
(300 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 8.28 (s, 1 H), 7.84 (s, 1 H), 7.72 (d, J = 9.0 Hz,
2 H), 7.63 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 2 H), 7.11 (s, 1 H). MS: m/z = 223.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM chemoselective
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Mild conditions for copper-catalyzed N-arylation of imidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Chen, Huaming; Wang, Deping; Wang, Xianyang; Huang, Wenlong; Cai, Qian;
Ding, Ke
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2010), (9), 1505-1511

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the N-arylation of
imidazoles with aryl bromides. An oven-dried screw-cap test tube was
charged with Cu2O (0.05 mmol), L1c (0.15 mmol), imidazole (1.2 mmol),
aryl bromide (1.00 mmol, if solid), poly(ethylene glycol) (200 mg),
Cs2CO3 (1.4 mmol), and a magnetic stir bar. The reaction vessel was
fitted with a rubber septum. The vessel was evacuated and back-filled
with argon or nitrogen, and this sequence was repeated an additional
time. Aryl bromide (1.00 mmol, if liquid), and solvent (0.5 mL) were then
added successively. The reaction tube was sealed, immersed, and stirred
in a preheated oil bath for the designated time period. The reaction
mixture was cooled to room temperature, diluted with dichloromethane (10
mL), filtered through a plug of celite, and eluted with additional
dichloromethane (50 mL). The filtrate was concentrated and the resulting
residue was purified by flash chromatography to provide the desired
product. 1-(4-tert-Butyl-phenyl)-1H-imidazole14 (2a)
3-Imidazol-1-yl-phenylamine (2c) The general procedure was followed using
Cu2O (7.2 mg, 0.05 mmol), L1c (36 mg, 0.15 mmol), PEG (200 mg), Cs2CO3
(0.45 g, 1.4 mmol), 3-bromoaniline (109 μL, 1.00 mmol), and imidazole (82
mg, 1.2 mmol) with butyronitrile (0.25 mL) as solvent for 20 h at 110 °C.
Chromatographic purification (ethyl acetate) afforded
3-imidazol-1-yl-phenylamine (white powder, 141 mg, 88%). 1H NMR (300 MHz,
CDCl3) δ 7.79 (bs, 1H), 7.21-7.15 (m, 3H), 6.72-6.68 (m, 1H), 6.64-6.60
(m, 2H). 4.01 (bs, 2H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 148.2, 138.4, 135.6,
130.7, 130.1, 118.4, 114.0, 111.1, 107.7. m.p. 112-114 °C (Lit. 111-113
°C).16
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Imidazoles and Benzimidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Altman, Ryan A.; Koval, Erica D.; Buchwald, Stephen L.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(16), 6190-6199

$DATUM 935547-42-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Catalytic
N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing Heterocycles with Aryl Halides. A
flame-dried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar was charged
with CuI (9.6 mg, 0.05 mmol), ligand (0.1 mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.652 g, 2.0
mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.0 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl
halide (1.2 mmol), and DMF (2 mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced
with a glass stopper, and the system was then evacuated twice and back
filled with N2. The reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room
temperature, and then heated to 110 °C for 24 h. The reaction mixture was
then cooled to ambient temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate,
filtered through a plug of silica gel, and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl
acetate. The filtrate was concentrated and the resulting residue was
purified by column chromatography on silica gel to provide the desired
product. 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (7a) 2 4-Imidazol-1-yl-benzonitrile (7d) 2
1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.27 (s, 1H), 7.35 (s, 1H), 7.54 (d, J = 8.4
Hz, 2H), 7.81 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 7.99 (s, 1H) ppm. 13C NMR (150 MHz,
CDCl3): δ 110.9, 117.5, 117.8, 121.3, 131.4, 134.1, 135.2, 140.4 ppm.
GC-MS (EI, m/z): 169 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Highly Efficient Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing
Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhu, Liangbo; Cheng, Liang; Zhang, Yuxi; Xie, Rugang; You, Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(8), 2737-2743

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2.2 Typical Experimental Procedure A mixture
of aryl halide (1 mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.5 mmol), Cu2O
(0.1 mmol), KOH (2 mmol) and DMSO (2 mL) was stirred at the temperature
specified under Ar atmosphere until nearly complete conversion of aryl
halide as monitored by GC or TLC, the cooled mixture was partitioned
between ethyl acetate (10 mL) and water (3 mL). The organic layer was
separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate (5 mL).
The combined organic layers were washed with brine (5 mL), dried over
Na2SO4, and concentrated to give the crude product, which was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel (200–300 mesh) using ethyl
acetate/methanol as eluent. Entry: 1 Yield: 90%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DATUM Catalysis Letters (2008), 122(3-4), 344-348

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Procedure B: Coupling of Aryl halides
with Amides, Imidazoles, Phenols or Thiols. (Table 2, entry 4): An
oven-dried Schlenk tube equipped with a Teflon valve was charged with a
magnetic stir bar, Cs2CO3 (684 mg, 2.1 mmol), CuBr (15 mg, 0.10 mmol, 10
mol%), and ethyl 2-oxocyclohexanecarboxylate (34 mg, 0.20 mmol, 20 mol%)
The tube was evacuated and backfilled with N2 (this procedure was
repeated three times). Under a counter flow of N2, DMSO (0.5 mL) was
added by syringe at room temperature (25-30 °C) and pre-stirred for 0.5
h. Then a solution of 1-iodo-4-methylbenzene (218 mg, 1.0 mmol),
2-pyrrolidinone (102 mg, 1.2 mmol) in DMSO (0.5 mL) was added via syringe
under a counter flow of N2. The tube was sealed and the mixture was
allowed to stir for 24 h at 60 ºC. The reaction mixture was directly
passed through celite. After rinsed with further 60 mL of ethyl acetate,
the combined filtrate was washed by saturated brine (10 ml × 2). After
the organic layer was dried by Na2SO4, it was concentrated by rotatory
evaporation. The residue was purified bycolumn chromatography on silica
gel using hexane/ethyl acetate (1:1) as eluent to give a white solid of
1-p-tolylpyrrolidin-2-one (151 mg, 86 %). 1d, 1-p-tolylpyrrolidin-2-one4
(Table 2, entry 4, 10) 2b, 1-(4-chlorophenyl)-1H-imidazole10 (Table 3,
entries 2 and 6) Procedure B was followed. Yellow solid; 1H NMR (400 MHz,
CDCl3) δ 7.82 (1 H, s), 7.43-7.46 (2H, m), 7.32-7.35 (2H, m), 7.25 (1H,
s), 7.21 (1 H, s); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 135.7, 135.4, 133.0, 130.6,
129.9, 122.6, 118.0 (CDCl3 δ 77.0).

$DATUM 92149-07-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-74-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the N-arylation of
imidazoles with aryl iodides. An oven-dried screw-cap test tube was
charged with Cu2O (0.025 mmol), L (0.075 mmol), imidazole (1.2 mmol),
aryl iodide (1.00 mmol, if solid), poly(ethylene glycol) (200 mg), Cs2CO3
(1.4 mmol), and a magnetic stir bar. The reaction vessel was fitted with
a rubber septum. The vessel was evacuated and back-filled with argon or
nitrogen, and this sequence was repeated an additional time. Aryl iodide
(1.00 mmol, if liquid) and solvent (0.5 mL) were then added successively.
The reaction tube was sealed, and stirred in a pre-heated oil bath for
the designated time period. The reaction mixture was cooled to room
temperature, diluted with dichloromethane (10 mL), and filtered through a
plug of celite, eluting with additional dichloromethane (50 mL). The
filtrate was concentrated and the resulting residue was purified by flash
chromatography to provide the desired product. Experimental procedures
for the N-arylation of imidazole with aryl iodides. 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole
1-Naphthalen-1-yl-1H-imidazole The general procedure was followed using
Cu2O (7.2 mg, 0.05 mmol), L (36 mg, 0.15 mmol), PEG (200 mg), Cs2CO3
(0.45 g, 1.4 mmol), 1-iodonaphthalene (146 μL, 1.00 mmol), and imidazole
(82 mg, 1.2 mmol) with NMP (0.3 mL) as solvent for 24 h at 110 °C. The
crude reaction mixture was dissolved in 20 mL of water, and extracted
with dichloromethane (5 x 30 mL). The combined organic layers were dried
with MgSO4, and the solvent was removed in vacuo. Chromatographic
purification (hexane / ethyl acetate 1 : 1) provided
1-naphthalen-1-yl-1H-imidazole (yellow-white solid, 179 mg, 92 %). 1H NMR
(300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.94-7.92 (m, 2H), 7.76, (bs, 1H), 7.61-7.48 (m, 4 H),
7.43 (d, 1H, J = 7.0 Hz), 7.30 (bs, 1H), 7.25 (bs, 1H). m.p. 63-64 °C
(Lit. 62 °C).10 A copy of the 1H NMR spectrum is provided.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM 4,7-Dimethoxy-1,10-phenanthroline: An excellent ligand for the
Cu-catalyzed N-arylation of imidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Altman, Ryan A.; Buchwald, Stephen L.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Organic Letters (2006), 8(13), 2779-2782

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME47 STEP1

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2.2 Typical Experimental Procedure A mixture
of aryl halide (1 mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.5 mmol), Cu2O
(0.1 mmol), KOH (2 mmol) and DMSO (2 mL) was stirred at the temperature
specified under Ar atmosphere until nearly complete conversion of aryl
halide as monitored by GC or TLC, the cooled mixture was partitioned
between ethyl acetate (10 mL) and water (3 mL). The organic layer was
separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate (5 mL).
The combined organic layers were washed with brine (5 mL), dried over
Na2SO4, and concentrated to give the crude product, which was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel (200–300 mesh) using ethyl
acetate/methanol as eluent. (b) 1-(3-Trifluoromethylphenyl)-1H-imidazole
(Table 2, entry 6), a colorless liquid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 7.92
(s, 1H), 7.66–7.61 (m, 4H), 7.34 (s, 1H), 7.25 (s, 1H) ppm; 13C NMR
(100.6 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 137.9, 135.6, 132.6 (q, 2 J CF = 33.2 Hz), 131.1,
130.8, 124.7, 124.3, 123.5 (q, 1 J CF = 272.6 Hz), 118.4, 118.2 ppm; GC/
MS (EI) m/z (%): 213 (12), 212 (100), 193 (10), 185 (56), 166 (6), 158
(29), 145 (34), 135 (5), 125 (7), 116 (5), 95 (9), 75 (7); IR (thin film,
neat) cm-1: 3115, 1599, 1506, 1373, 1326, 1254, 1172, 1129, 1063, 896,
802, 699, 657.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

Nitrogen-containing Heterocycles with Aryl Halides

$DATUM Huang, Yi-Zheng; Miao, Hong; Zhang, Qiao-Hong; Chen, Chen; Xu, Jie

$DATUM Catalysis Letters (2008), 122(3-4), 344-348

$DATUM 91
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 528818-81-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Markovnikov Addition
of 4-nitroimidazole to Vinyl acetate promoted by ionic liquid [bmIm]OH.
4-nitroimidazole (113 mg, 1 mmol) and vinyl acetate (344 mg, 4 mmol) were
added to a 10 mL conical flask containing 1 ml [bmim]OH and the mixture
was shaken at 200 rpm and 50°C for 2 h. The reaction mixture was
extracted from the ionic liquid phase with ethyl ether (10.0 mL×5). The
organic layer was dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate and evaporated
under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by flash column
chromatography (silica gel) to obtain the pure product 3a,
1-(1-(4-nitroimidazole))-ethyl acetate (186 mg, 93%).
1-(1-imidazole)-ethyl acetate (3g): colorless oil. IR (neat): 1749,1514
cm-1; 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 500 MHz, δ, ppm): 7.86 (s, 1H), 7.39 (s, 1H), 6.93
(s, 1H), 6.72 (q, 1H, J=6.21 Hz), 2.01 (s, 3H), 1.71 (d, 3H, J=6.21 Hz).
13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 125 MHz, δ, ppm): 169.7, 137.3, 129.3, 117.8, 76.2,
21.2, 20.4. HRMS (ESI) m/z calcd. for [M + H] C7H11N2O2 155.0815, found
155.0813.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry-solvent, regioselective, ionic liq. also used as solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Basic Ionic Liquid as Catalysis and Reaction Medium: A Novel and Green
Protocol for the Markovnikov Addition of N-Heterocycles to Vinyl Esters,
Using a Task-Specific Ionic Liquid, [bmIm]OH
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Xu, Jian-Ming; Liu, Bo-Kai; Wu, Wei-Bo; Qian, Chao; Wu, Qi; Lin, Xian-Fu
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2006), 71(10), 3991-3993

$DATUM 67-64-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 1-Dodecyl-1H-imidazole. A mixture of 4.1 g (0.06 mol) of imidazole, 14.4
ml (0.06 mol) of 1-bromododecane (Aldrich, ⩾97%), and 3.9 (0.07 mol) of
thoroughly ground potassium hydroxide in 60 ml of anhydrous acetone was
heated for 8 h under reflux. The mixture was evaporated on a rotary
evaporator, and the residue was distilled under reduced pressure. Yield
13.0 g (92%). bp 165-170°C (0.5-0.8 mm). 1H NMR spectrum (CDCl3), δ, ppm:
0.88 t (3H, CH3, J = 6.8 Hz), 1.19-1.40 m [18H, (CH2)9], 1.71-1.81 m (2H,
CH2), 3.92 t (2H, CH2 N, J = 7.2 Hz), 6.90 s (1H, Harom), 7.05 s (1H,
Harom), 7.48 s (1H, Harom). Found, %: C 76.24; H 11.92; N 11.83.
C15H28N2. Calculated, %: C 76.21; H 11.94; N 11.85.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Supernucleophilic systems based on functionalized surfactants in the
decomposition of 4-nitrophenyl esters derived from phosphorus and sulfur
acids: I. Reactivity of a hydroxyimino derivative of gemini imidazolium
surfactant
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kapitanov, I. V.; Belousova, I. A.; Shumeiko, A. E.; Kostrikin, M. L.;
Prokop'eva, T. M.; Popov, A. F.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Russian Journal of Organic Chemistry (2013), 49(9), 1291-1299

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the N-arylation of
imidazoles with aryl iodides. An oven-dried screw-cap test tube was
charged with Cu2O (0.025 mmol), L1c (0.075 mmol), imidazole (1.2 mmol),
aryl iodide (1.00 mmol, if solid), poly(ethylene glycol) (200 mg), Cs2CO3
(1.4 mmol), and a magnetic stir bar. The reaction vessel was fitted with
a rubber septum. The vessel was evacuated and back-filled with argon or
nitrogen, and this sequence was repeated an additional time. Aryl iodide
(1.00 mmol, if liquid) and solvent (0.5 mL) were then added successively.
The reaction tube was sealed, and stirred in a pre-heated oil bath for
the designated time period. The reaction mixture was cooled to room
temperature, diluted with dichloromethane (10 mL), and filtered through a
plug of celite, eluting with additional dichloromethane (50 mL). The
filtrate was concentrated and the resulting residue was purified by flash
chromatography to provide the desired product. 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (1a)
1-(3-Nitro-phenyl)-1H-imidazole (1c) The general procedure was followed
using Cu2O (3.6 mg, 0.025 mmol), L1c (18 mg, 0.075 mmol), PEG (200 mg),
Cs2CO3 (0.45 g, 1.4 mmol), 3-nitroiodobenzene (249 mg, 1.00 mmol), and
imidazole (83 mg, 1.2 mmol) with acetonitrile (0.5 mL) as solvent for 29
h at 80 °C. Chromatographic purification (hexane / ethyl acetate 1 : 3)
1-(3-nitro-phenyl)-1H-imidazole (white solid, 177 mg, 93%). 1H NMR (500
MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.25 (t, 1H, J = 1.9), 8.19 (ddd, 1H, J = 1.1, 1.9, 7.9
Hz), 7.94 (s, 1H), 7.75 (ddd, 1H, J = 1.4, 2.2, 8.1 Hz), 7.69 (t, 1H, J =
8.0 Hz), 7.36 (s, 1H), 7.23 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 149.1,
138.3, 125.5, 131.5, 131.2, 126.9, 122.1, 118.0, 116.2. m.p. 109-110 °C
(Lit. 109-110 °C).7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Imidazoles and Benzimidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Altman, Ryan A.; Koval, Erica D.; Buchwald, Stephen L.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(16), 6190-6199

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Procedure of N-Arylation
Under Homogeneous Conditions Catalyst 1f (0.007 g, 1 mol%), K2CO3 (0.276
g, 2 mmol) were added to a mixture of 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene (0.158 g, 1
mmol) and imidazole (0.081 g, 1.2 mmol) in 3 mL of DMF. The reaction
mixture was heated at 110 °C under stirring for 1.5 h. After cooling to
ambient temperature, the resulting mixture was added with 4 mL of ethyl
acetate and 10 mL of water. The organic layer was separated, and the
aqueous layer was further extracted with ethyl acetate (10 mL). The
combined organic phase was washed with brine and dried over Na2SO4. The
solvent was removed under vacuum, and the residue was further purified by
flash-column chromatography on silica gel to afford the product
1-(4-nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole in 94% yield. Table 4, Entry 7, yield 92%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-Arylation of heterocycles with chloro- and fluoroarenes using
resin-supported sulfonato-Cu(salen) complex
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kantam, M. Lakshmi; Ramani, T.; Chakrapani, L.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2008), 38(4), 626-636

$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: A typical procedure for N-arylation of
imidazole with chloroarenes In a typical experimental procedure,
chlorobenzene (0.1 mL, 1 mmol), imidazole (81 mg, 1.2 mmol), potassium
carbonate (276 mg, 2 mmol), potassium tert-butoxide (11 mg, 10 mol% in
case of electron rich chloroarenes only) and the catalyst (CuFAP, 100 mg)
were stirred in DMF (4 mL) at 120°C for 36 h. After 36 h, the catalyst
was filtered and the filtrate was quenched with aqueous sodium hydrogen
carbonate and the product was extracted with ethyl acetate. The combined
organic extracts were dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered.
Solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure and concentrated in vacuo
to give the crude product. The crude product was purified by column
chromatography on silica gel (hexane/ethyl acetate, 70/30) to afford the
N-phenylimidazole (115 mg, 80%, Table1, entry 9,). The known coupling
products are well compared with the reported spectral data and melting
points. For the new compounds HRMS data are included.
1-(4-Formylphenyl)-1H-imidazole 13) 1-(4-Formylphenyl)-1H-imidazole
(Table 1, entry 13). 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3): δ=10.02 (s, 1H), 8.00 (d,
2H, J = 8.3 Hz), 7.93 (br s, 1H), 7.57 (d, 2H, J = 8.3 Hz), 7.33 (br s, 1
H), 7.21 (br s, 1H); EI-MS: 172, 143, 116, 89, 77, 51, 43; GC/MS: tR =
21.6 min; m/z : 172.25; IR: (KBr) cm-1: 3110.95, 1687.04, 1526.81,
1312.79, 1222.12, 1062.90, 834.15, 649.93.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, copper-exchanged fluorapatite used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Design and Evolution of Copper Apatite Catalysts for N-Arylation of
Heterocycles with Chloro- and Fluoroarenes
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Choudary, Boyapati M.; Sridhar, Chidara; Kantam, Mannepalli L.; Venkanna,
Gopaldasu T.; Sreedhar, Bojja
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127(28), 9948-9949

$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM N-Ethylhexyl-3-imidazolium carbazole (3) A mixture of
N-ethylhexyl-3-bromocarbazole (6 g, 16.7 mmol), imidazole (1.24 , 18.3
mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline(0.65 g, 3.6 mmol), CuI (0.31 g, 1.66 mmol) and
K2CO3 (5.75 g, 0.042 mmol) in anhydrous DMF ( 50 ml) was stirred for 30
minutes at room temperature and then refluxed at 150oC under N2 for 30h
and cooled to room temperature. DMF was removed under high vacuum and
temperature. The resulting brown solid was dissolved in water and
extracted with dichloromethane. The organic extract was then dried over
anhydrous Na2SO4. Dichloromethane was removed under high vacuum. The
impure product was purified by silica gel column chromatography using
ethyl acetate: hexane (1:1) to obtain the pure compound. Light brown
solid, yield 5.24 g, 91%. 1H-NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ 8.11 (d, J= 7.76Hz,
1H), 8.06 (s, 1H), 7.89 (s, 1H), 7.52- 7.42 (m, 4H), 7.27 (s, 1H), 7.26
(t, 1H), 7.24 (s, 1H), 4.21 (m, 1H), 2.04 (m,4H), 1.27-1.26 (m, 6H), 0.93
(t, 3H), 0.86 (t, 3H) (MS, ESI) m/z 346 (M+).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM Ullmann reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Carbazole-Derived Group of Uniform Materials Based on Organic Salts:
Solid State Fluorescent Analogues of Ionic Liquids for Potential
Applications in Organic-Based Blue Light-Emitting Diodes
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Siraj, Noureen; Hasan, Farhana; Das, Susmita; Kiruri, Lucy W.; Steege
Gall, Karen E.; Baker, Gary A.; Warner, Isiah M.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2014), 118(5), 2312-2320

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the N-arylation of
imidazoles with aryl iodides. An oven-dried screw-cap test tube was
charged with Cu2O (0.025 mmol), L (0.075 mmol), imidazole (1.2 mmol),
aryl iodide (1.00 mmol, if solid), poly(ethylene glycol) (200 mg), Cs2CO3
(1.4 mmol), and a magnetic stir bar. The reaction vessel was fitted with
a rubber septum. The vessel was evacuated and back-filled with argon or
nitrogen, and this sequence was repeated an additional time. Aryl iodide
(1.00 mmol, if liquid) and solvent (0.5 mL) were then added successively.
The reaction tube was sealed, and stirred in a pre-heated oil bath for
the designated time period. The reaction mixture was cooled to room
temperature, diluted with dichloromethane (10 mL), and filtered through a
plug of celite, eluting with additional dichloromethane (50 mL). The
filtrate was concentrated and the resulting residue was purified by flash
chromatography to provide the desired product. Experimental procedures
for the N-arylation of imidazole with aryl iodides. 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole
1-(2-Isopropyl-phenyl)-1H-imidazole The general procedure was followed
using Cu2O (3.6 mg, 0.025 mmol), L (18 mg, 0.075 mmol), PEG (200 mg),
Cs2CO3 (0.45 g, 1.4 mmol), 2-isopropyl iodobenzene (246 mg, 1.00 mmol),
and imidazole (82 mg, 1.2 mmol) with butyronitrile (0.5 mL) as solvent
for 48 h at 110 °C. Chromatographic purification (hexane / ethyl acetate
1 : 1) provided 1-(2-isopropyl-phenyl)-1H-imidazole (white crystals, 171
mg, 92 %). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.57 (bs, 1H), 7.46-7.42 (m, 2H),
7.31-7.11 (m, 3H), 7.05 (m, bs), 2.74 (heptet, 1H, J = 6.9 Hz), 1.16 (d,
6H, J = 6.9 Hz). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 145.0, 135.1, 129.4, 129.2,
127.0, 126.7, 126.4, 121.1, 27.4, 24.0. m.p. 76-77 °C (Lit. 67-68 °C).8
Anal. Calc. for C12H14N2: C 77.38, H 7.58. Found: C 77.42, H 7.78. A copy
of the 1H NMR spectrum is provided.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DATUM Preparation of [(SC6H4-o-NHCOPh)(Im)Fe(NO)2] (Im = imidazole) (2).
Addition of 2 equiv of imidazole (0.014 g, 0.2 mmol) to the THF solution
of complex 1 (0.069 g, 0.1 mmol) under N2 atmosphere at room temperature
and stirred for 5 min. The reaction was monitored with FT-IR (IR (THF):
1722 vs, 1786 vs cm-1 (νNO)) were assigned to the formation of
[(SC6H4-o-NHCOPh)(Im)Fe(NO) 2]. The resulting solution was dried under a
gentle stream of N2 bubbling. Diffusion of hexane into the diethyl ether
of complex 2 at -15 °C for 2 weeks gave dark red-brown crystals
[(SC6H4-o-NHCOPh)(Im)Fe(NO) 2] (2), yield 0.077 g, 93 %. IR (νNO): 1722
s, 1786 s (THF) cm-1 . Absorption spectrum (CH2Cl2) [λmax, nm (ε, M-1
cm-1 )]: 378(5091), 450(2000), 787(319). Anal. Calcd for C16H14O3SN5Fe:
C, 46.62; H, 3.42; N, 16.99. Found: C, 47.02; H, 3.60; N, 16.80.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM under positive pressure of N2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Neutral {Fe(NO)2}9 Dinitrosyliron Complex (DNIC)
[(SC6H4-o-NHCOPh)(Im)Fe(NO)2] (Im = Imidazole): Interconversion among the
Anionic/Neutral {Fe(NO)2}9 DNICs and Roussin's Red Ester
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Tsai, Ming-Li; Liaw, Wen-Feng

ml distilled water was added. Filtration of solid. 0.38 g (93%) of
compound 9. 1H NMR (CDCl3) 7.51 (s, 2H), 6.99 (m, 18H), 6.51 (d, 2H, J =
8.0), 6.37 (d, 2H, J = 8.0), 5.35 (d, 2H, J = 14.0), 5.12 (d, 2H, J =

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Synthesis of
1-(3-Aryloxy-3- arypropyl)-1H-imidazoles 11, 15-28, 30-37, and 39-50.
Example. 1-(3-Phenoxy-3-phenylpropyl)-1H-imidazole (11). A mixture of 77
(0.54 g, 0.0022 mol) and imidazole (0.49 g, 0.0072 mol) in anhydrous DMF
(3.49 mL) was refluxed for 24 h. After cooling, the reaction mixture was
diluted with water and extracted with ethyl acetate. The organic layer
was separated, washed with brine, and dried. Removal of the solvent gave
a crude product, which was purified on silica gel columm (ethyl acetate
as eluent) to afford 11. Yield 59%, as a yellow oil.
1-(3-Phenyl-3-oxopropyl)-1H-imidazole (115). 115 was prepared as 11 using
57. Yield 93%, white solid, mp 90-94 °C (from cyclohexane). 1H NMR
(CDCl3): δ 3.44 (t, J = 6.54 Hz, 2H), 4.43 (t, J = 6.54 Hz, 2H),
6.96-6.97 (m, 1H), 7.02-7.03 (m, 1H), 7.44-7.48 (m, 2H), 7.55-7.60 (m,
2H), 7.89-7.82 ppm (m, 2H).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Intermediate 16: 2-fluoro-6-[4-(1H-imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-2-methoxyphenoxy]
pyridine To a solution of imidazole (18 mg; 0.27 mmol) and NaH (12 mg;
0.30 mmol) in DMF (1 mL), under argon, was added a solution of
2-[4-(chloromethyl)-2-methoxyphenoxy]-6-fluoropyridine (65 mg; 0.24 mmol)
in DMF (1 mL). The reaction mixture was allowed to stir overnight, to
40°C. After concentration, the reaction was hydrolysed with saturated
NH4Cl (1 mL), extracted with AcOEt (2*1 mL). Combined organic phases were
dried over Na2SO4, concentrated in vacuo, the title compound was
obtained. Yield 68 mg, 93 %. MS (ES) m/e 300 (M+H)+.

$DATUM 31-614-CAS-30538915

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-05-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Difluoromethylation of Imidazoles Using Solid-Phase Bound Reagent To a
solution of imidazole derivative (0.25 mmol) in dry acetonitrile (4 mL)
solidphase bound difluoromethylating reagent (in case of N-alkyl
imidazoles 300 mg resin 0.35 mmol, in case of N-unsubstituted imidazoles
600 mg = 0.7 mmol S-difluoromethylsulphonium derivative) and
morpholinimethylpolystyrene (in case of N-alkyl imidazoles 100 mg resin
0.4 mmol, in case of not N-substituted imidazoles 200 mg = 0.8 mmol
solid-phase supported morpholine) were added. The reaction mixture was
stirred 24 hours at room temperature. The resin was filtered off and
washed with acetonitrile (5 × 5 mL). The solvent was removed in vacuum to
give the expected product as a white solid or colorless semisolid.
N,N'-Bis(difluoromethyl)imidazolium Tetrafluoroborate. Yield: 93%.
Yellowish semi solid. 1H-NMR (CD3CN): 7.64 (t, JH-F = 59.10 Hz, 2H), 7.96
(s, 2H), 9.52 (s, 1H). 19F-NMR (CD3CN): -97.04 (d, 4F, JH-F = 59.10 Hz),
-150.18 (s, 1F), -150.23 (s, 3F). 13C-NMR (CD3CN): 109.7 (t, JC-F = 261.3
Hz), 121.1, 136.6. HRMS calculated for C5H5F2N4. Expected: 169.0389.
Found: 169.0383.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported reaction, mopholinimethylpolystyrene used

$DATUM 67-66-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Procedure for the preparation of N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl imidazole. To a
solution of 0.14 mol of imidazole (9.54 g) in 50 mL of CHCl3, triethyl
amine (18 mL, 0.13 mol) and N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl chloride (13 mL) were
added. The reaction mixture was stirred overnight at RT. After stirring,
the reaction mixture was washed with H2O (50 mL). The organic layer was
then concentrated to a small volume under vacuum, diluted with normal
hexane, and shaken vigorously by hand. A white precipitate was at once
formed and recovered by filtration. Yield: 92 %, White solid. 1H-NMR
(CDCl3, 400 MHz): 2.87 (s, 6H), 7.16 (s, 1H), 7.28 (s, 1H), 7.92 (s, 1H),
13C-NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz): 38.5, 117.9, 131.5, 138.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM literature procedure
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A novel method for the one-pot conversion of carboxylic acids to
N,N-dimethylamides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kaboudin, Babak; Haghighat, Hamideh
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the Iranian Chemical Society (2012), 9(6), 951-955

$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Imidazole-1-sulfonic acid dimethylamide (40). Imidazole (63 g, 926 mmol)
was dissolved in DCM (400 mL) and TEA (153 mL) and
N,N-dimethylsulfamoylchloride (100 mL, 926 mmol) was added dropwise to
this mixture. After stirring at r.t. overnight, a potassium carbonate
solution (10 % in water) was added, the layers were separated and the
organic layer was dried on Na2SO4 and evaporated in vacuo. Yield = 147 g
(843 mol, 91%). 1H-NMR (CDCl3) δ 7.82 (s, 1H, Im-2H), 7.28 (s, 1H,
Im-5H), 7.05 (s, 1H, Im-4H), 2.79 (s, 6H, CH3).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

Agonists

$DATUM 616-47-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Michael Addition; General Procedure
4-Nitroimidazole (1 mmol) and α ,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds (1.2
mmol) were added to a solution of N-methylimidazole (0.05 equiv) in DMSO
(1 mL) and the mixture was shaken at 200 rpm and 70 °C for 1 h. The
reaction mixture was purified by flash column chromatography (silica gel)
to obtain the corresponding Michael adduct. 4-(Imidazol-1-yl)butan-2-one
(3i)16c Colorless oil, yield 92% IR (neat): 1715, 1508 cm-1. 1H NMR
(CDCl3): δ = 7.48 (s, 1 H), 6.99 (s, 1 H), 6.92 (s, 1 H), 4.22 (t, J =
6.4 Hz, 2 H), 2.92 (t, J = 6.4 Hz, 2 H), 2.14 (s, 3 H). 13C NMR (CDCl3):
δ = 205.2, 137.2, 129.1, 119.0, 44.4, 40.8, 30.1. ESI-MS: m/z = 139 [M +
1].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM aza-Michael addition reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-Methylimidazole as a promising catalyst for the aza-Michael addition
reaction of N-heterocycles

$DATUM Synthesis (2007), (17), 2653-2659

$DATUM 584-08-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7681-65-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 25322-68-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Coupling Reaction A
Schlenk tube with a magnetic stirring bar was charged with imidazole (2.4
mmol), K2CO3 (4.2 mmol), CuI (0.16 mmol, 10 mol%), aryl halide (2.0
mmol), and PEG (3 mL). The tube was sealed after being evacuated twice
and back filled with N2. The mixture was stirred at 110°C for 24 h,
cooled to room temperature, and extracted with diethyl ether (5×10mL).
The upper layers were decanted, combined, and concentrated to the crude
product, which was analyzed by GC-MS. The PEG phase of the lower layer
was subjected to a second run with the same substrates. Further
purification of the product was achieved by flash chromatography on a
silica-gel column. All the products, which are known compounds, were
characterized and compared with authentic compounds previously reported
in the literatures.[9a,9b,12,15] 1-(3-Trifluoromethylphenyl)-1H-imidazole
(Table 2, Entry 3). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.92 (s, 1H), 7.67-7.61 (m,
4H), 7.34 (s, 1H), 7.26 (s, 1H). GC-MS (EI, m/z): 211.9 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Efficient and Reusable Catalytic System of CuI-PEG for N-Arylation of
Imidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhang, Qiang; Luo, Jun; Wei, Yunyang
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2012), 42(1), 114-121

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-363-CAS-14690441
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 93
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 107-06-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Example 2: Preparation of sorafenib base. To a solution of the imidazole
complex of imidazole-1-carboxylic acid 4-chloro-3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl
amide of formula 4a (8.5 g) in 1,2-dichloroethane (60 g) at 60 °C,
4-(4-aminophenoxy)-N-methyl-2-pyridinecarboxamide (4.5 g) was added, and
the mixture was kept under stirring at 60-65 °C for 15 minutes until a
precipitate formed. The suspension was allowed to cool slowly to 20 °C,
and then stirred for 16 hours. The precipitate was filtered off, washed
with 1,2-dichloroethane and dried at 50 °C under vacuum overnight.
Sorafenib base was obtained as a colorless powder (8 g, 93% yield, 99.9%
purity).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Process for preparation of sorafenib and intermediates thereof
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Rossetto, Pierluigi; Macdonald, Peter Lindsay; Canavesi, Augusto
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2009111061 A1 2009-09-11

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME106 STEP1
$RXN

$DATUM 75-05-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Step 1. 4-(1-Imidazolylmethyl)-1-nitrobenzene: To a solution of imidazole
(0.5 g, 7.3 mmol) and 4-nitrobenzyl bromide (1.6 g, 7.3 mmol) in anh
acetonitrile (30 mL) was added K2CO3 (1.0 g, 7.3 mmol). The resulting
mixture was stirred at room temp. for 18 h and then poured into water
(200 mL) and the resulting aqueous solution was extracted with EtOAc
(3×50 mL). The combined organic layers were sequentially washed with
water (3×50 mL) and a saturated NaCl solution (2×50 mL), dried (MgSO4),
and concentrated in vacuo. The residual oil was purified by MPLC (silica
gel; 25% EtOAc/75% hexane). The desired product (1.0 g, 91%): EI-MS m/z
203 (M+).

$DATUM B8. General Method for Synthesis of Aryl Amines Via Substitution with
Nitrobenzyl Halides Followed by Reduction. Step 1.
4-(1-Imidazolylmethyl)-1-nitrobenzene: To a solution of imidazole (O.S g,
7.3 mmol) and 4-nitrobenzyl bromide (1.6 g, 7.3 mmol) in anh acetonitrile
(30 mL) was added K2CO3 (1.0 g, 7.3 mmol). The resulting mixture was
stirred at room temp. for 18 h and then poured into water (200 mL) and
the resulting aqueous solution was extracted with EtOAc (3×50 mL). The
combined organic layers were sequentially washed with water (3×50 mL) and
a saturated NaCl solution (2×50 mL), dried (MgSO4), and concentrated in
vacuo. The residual oil was purified by MPLC (silica gel; 25% EtOAc/75%
hexane) to afford the desired product (1.0 g, 91%). EI-MS m/z 203 (MO).
